title: Jane Addams
summary: Laura Jane Addams[1] (September 6, 1860 –  May 21, 1935) was an American settlement activist, reformer, social worker,[2][3] sociologist,[4] public administrator[5][6] and author. She was an important leader in the history of social work and women's suffrage in the United States and advocated for world peace.[7] She co-founded Chicago's Hull House, one of America's most famous settlement houses. In 1910, Addams was awarded an honorary master of arts degree from Yale University, becoming the first woman to receive an honorary degree from the school.[8] In 1920, she was a co-founder of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU).[9]
